Award.AwardTitle: SCC-CIVIC-PG Track A: Community Based Ride-Hail Pilot: One Car, Multiple Opportunities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Decades of evidence suggests that car access provides significant advantages in the labor market. Yet for many, cars are financially out of reach. This project proposes to create a community-based ride-hail program to better connect communities with opportunities. The project team's community partner organization, Vehicles for Change (VFC), will subsidize vehicles to low-income, car-less individuals living in Baltimore. In return, recipients will provide a number of weekly rides to other car-less Baltimore residents to access employment and essential services. The program expands VFC’s existing vehicle subsidy program and connections within the community. This pilot will enable VFC to connect multiple people—rather than single households—to essential services for every car they distribute. If the project team can provide 50 cars for this pilot, the project can enable hundreds of residents to access jobs, healthcare, and educational opportunities. The project will evaluate the success of community ride-hail using original survey data of program drivers and riders, as well as a control group comprised of those on the waiting list to receive a vehicle from VFC. Measures of success would include employment and earnings data—among others—for drivers, riders, and wait-listed individuals. Program evaluation will significantly advance knowledge by assessing whether the effects of car access could be “multiplied” by linking subsidized car ownership to a low-cost ride-hail service for other car-less people.

The goal of this project is to assess the viability of a community-based ride-hail program that connects low-income residents to jobs and other essential services. This project plans to evaluate the economic and non- economic benefits of this program for both drivers and riders. For drivers, the project team plans to employ a panel- survey to assess the short- and medium-term effects of participating in this program, and compare the results with a control group drawn from the community partners’ networks. The team will augment the panel surveys with interviews with drivers and surveys of riders to provide a robust understanding of both qualitative and quantifiable effects of a community ride-hail program to inform best practices for scalable and transferable programs. This project is supported by the CIVIC Innovation Challenge program Track A. Communities and Mobility: Offering Better Mobility Options to Solve the Spatial Mismatch Between Housing Affordability and Jobs through a collaboration between NSF and the Department of Energy Vehicle Transportation Office.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Decades of transportation research finds that cars greatly expand workers' access to employment opportunities; yet, expanding car ownership runs counter to transportation policies focused on curtailing automobility and its negative consequences. In this project, we conducted surveys of 830 and interviewed 29 lower-income adults; these activities supported Stage 1 research efforts to draft a full grant proposal for the Smart and Connected Communities program. The proposed program, Community Based Ride-hail: One Car, Multiple Opportunities, would test the relative social, economic, and mobility benefits of three programs operated simultaneously and each aimed at connecting low-income travelers to opportunities: (1) subsidize cars for 40 low-income house households (2) create a monthly Uber voucher program offering 100 participants $50 per month in Uber credit; and (3) launch a pooled ride-hail van service to/from large employment centers in Baltimore to respond to a growing need for reliable transportation to connect communities to high-paying but spatially distant jobs.

 

Stage 1 research provided direct imperative for the programs proposed in this pilot, as well as shaped individual program facets. During Stage 1, the research team completed three research tasks: first, the team conducted interviews with 29 Baltimore residents who do not own cars and earn under $50,000 per year. The interviews focused on transportation challenges, understanding how interviewees use ride-hail services, and barriers they face that the proposed pilot would need to overcome in order to deliver meaningful transportation change. Second, the team surveyed 830 low-income households drawn from an online panel to understand car access, ride-hail use, ride-hail barriers, technology access, and stated interest in proposed programs.

 

Findings from Stage 1 activities revealed substantial transportation hardship among zero-car, low-income travelers in Baltimore. Interviewees discussed 'working 12-to-13-hour days even though you're at an eight-hour shift' due to long and indirect transit routes, and how transportation options themselves limited job opportunities because 'there's a lot of good jobs that pay more money further out[side]' of the city inaccessible via fixed public transit routes. Interviewees stressed the need for reliable and affordable transportation, with many stating that ride-hail services, including Uber and Lyft, helped to fill in their transportation gaps when the weather was poor, to get to and from work, and when their car broke down. Yet interviewees also noted that costs prohibited them from using ride-hail more frequently or at all saying: 'if I got extra money, I will catch a Lyft...[but] I don't have that kind of money.' Results from the low-income panel survey echoed the challenges of traveling without a car; 24% of travelers without a car said that getting to places they need to go is 'somewhat' to 'very' difficult compared to 5% of surveyed travelers who own a car. Survey results also highlighted the relative popularity of using ride- hail services--at least occasionally--among low-income travelers; of surveyed travelers, 75% have taken at least one ride-hail trip for purposes like going to work (27%) and buying groceries (31%). Many highlighted that they took ride-hail when there were no other modes available at the times or places they needed to travel and that ride-hail was often the fastest and safest way to reach their destination. About one-third (32%) of respondents indicated that trip cost was an impediment to taking ride-hail more frequently.

 

Stage 1 activities directly informed the project team's Stage 2 grant proposal for the Smart and Connected Communities grant program, including the interventions proposed in the pilot program. Proposed Stage 2 components reflect demonstrated transportation needs backed by survey and interview research conducted in this project. Research findings also expand academic literature and understanding of how lower-income travelers access opportunities and the many challenges they face within the current transportation system.
